A man beat his girlfriend to death the told police “I’ve beaten her up and now she’s dead," a court heard 
Jordan Matthews, 24, is standing trial accused of the murder of his girlfriend of Xixi Bi, 24. 
Cardiff Crown Court heard yesterday that Matthews told police “I’ve beaten her up and now she’s dead." 
He also told police he was a black belt in karate, but said he was “not that strong” and was surprised by how hard he hit Ms Bi, the jury heard. 
The defendant told officers he had never hit a woman before and thought it was “disgusting” to do so but he "accepts he is guilty of the manslaughter of Ms Bi." 
Opening the case, prosecutor Paul Lewis QC told the jury the defendant had made a 999 call just before 8.30am on August 19 last year from his home address in Ely Road. Xixi Bi found dead at her home (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) Jordan Matthews is on trial for murder (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
He said: “The defendant was attempting to contact the ambulance service, but spoke to a police officer. 
“During the phone call he said: ‘Well me and her had a bicker last night and I have ADHD and I hit her a few times and we were ok and she was talking to me and we were fine and she fell asleep. 
"'Then I have been really horrible to her this last day and now she is struggling to breathe.’" 
The court heard Ms Bi was found by paramedics and police lying on her back and not breathing and was rushed to the University Hospital of Wales, Cardiff. Cardiff Crown Court heard today that Matthews told police “I’ve beaten her up and now she’s dead" (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) The court heard Xixi Bi was found by paramedics and police lying on her back and not breathing (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
She was found to be in cardiac arrest and she was pronounced dead just after 9.30am, reports Wales Online . 
A post-mortem found “numerous and widespread” bruises. 
The trial heard a pathologist found a number of healing rib fractures, he thought were caused in the weeks before her death. 
Some of those had been recently re-fractured and there were also fractures to her jaw. 
The court was told a pathologist concluded the injuries Ms Bi suffered were typical of a “severe assault” that involved “dozens” of impacts. The prosecutor said Ms Bi, who was 5ft 1in tall and weighed 7st 9lb, had tried to defend herself (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) The court was told a pathologist concluded the injuries Ms Bi suffered were typical of a “severe assault” that involved “dozens” of impacts (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
The prosecutor said Ms Bi, who was 5ft 1in tall and weighed 7st 9lb, had tried to defend herself. 
The court heard she suffered “extensive soft tissue injuries” and multiple injuries to her head, trunk and legs. 
Mr Lewis said: “In essence, the prosecution alleges the defendant beat Ms Bi to death in her own home in a vicious, sustained and prolonged attack.” 
He said: “We submit he is guilty, not of manslaughter, but of murder.” 
The jury was also read extracts from the defendant's police interview in which he told officers he found a message on Ms Bi's phone from someone called Ben. The court heard Matthews told police he felt “guilty” when he saw Ms Bi’s bruises and kissed them (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
He said when he asked her about it, she became evasive. 
Matthews said he followed her into the living room, asking: “What have you done?” 
He described himself as “very angry” and accepted pushing her with his hands. 
The defendant described his girlfriend as “flappy” and said he grabbed her by her top, pulled her towards the doorway and used a “pull throw” technique to launch her into the bedroom. 
He said she “bounced off” the door frame. He accepted she told him her arm was “killing her”. Matthews described the incident as “a little hiccup” (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
Matthews told officers he threw her again when she did not answer and she hit a chest of drawers. 
He said he went towards her intending to pick her up and then remembered something she said and punched her with his fist. 
He told police he felt “guilty” when he saw Ms Bi’s bruises and kissed them. 
He said she had “no life in her” the next morning. 
Matthews described the incident as “a little hiccup”. 
He denied ever being violent towards his girlfriend in the past and claimed the only other time he had laid hands on her was grabbing her to stop her from getting run over by a bus. 
The trial continues.
